title: Aussie links in Thomas Cook collapse
text:
RBS’s role in the collapse has been a point of controversy, with the Thomas Cook camp laying some of the blame for the collapse of a £900 million rescue deal from Chinese group Fosun at the feet of the bank.

Reports have suggested lenders including RBS asked for an extra £200 million in liquidity – apparently to get through the quieter winter months – before they would back the rescue deal.

RBS has challenged this characterisation, and pointed to its support for the struggling business over a long period.

Whatever the case, this brings us to the next Australian connection.

Reports over the weekend suggested that one of those tapped to provide that extra £200 million was the hedge fund CQS Management, the $25 billion money manager owned by Sir Michael Hintze.

The biggest and most obvious link between Thomas Cook and Australia is at listed group Webjet, which said on Monday it was owed $43.6 million by the British group.

The two companies established a deal in August 2016, under which Webjet’s European online accommodation subsidiary, now known as WebBeds, paid Thomas Cook £21 million to take over the majority of the volume from Thomas Cook’s complementary hotel business, including 3000 hotel contracts.

This will hit earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation to the tune of $7 million, which is slightly above what analyst Tim Piper at RBC had expected. But given consensus EBITDA for the 2020 financial year will still be around $160 million (up from $126 million in 2019) the hit isn’t too brutal.

Advertisement

The 2.9 per cent fall in the Webjet share price on Monday was reasonably restrained. But with the stock now down 32 per cent in the last 12 months, the Thomas Cook collapse isn't news that investors or chief executive John Guscic really needed.

The eulogies for Thomas Cook will no doubt focus on its rich history: the founding of the business in 1841 by cabinetmaker-turned entrepreneur; the first package holiday in 1855; the creation of the forerunner of the travellers cheque in 1874; state ownership in 1948; and privatisation in 1972.

But the company’s more recent history appears to be the story of a company trying to grow its way to survival.

Six years after being acquired by German travel group Condor & Neckermann, Thomas Cook merged with MyTravel Group in 2007. Four years later – after almost collapsing – Thomas Cook merged its British retail operations with that of the Co-operative Group and the Midlands Co-operative Society, creating the UK's largest chain of travel agents.

The idea that even four years ago you would be trying to build the biggest chain in any retail sector seems farcical. The idea that any CEO, banker or adviser would suggest this could work in an industry as badly disrupted as travel is extraordinary.
description: The collapse of iconic British travel group Thomas Cook has some fascinating links to some big names in Australian business.
